body:
You can find an example here:
https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/e00ad83f2b3181eb6e3901fcf78a0d00c0306a04/onnxruntime/test/providers/cpu/tensor/tensor_op_test.cc#L186

Uh, let me elaborate a bit. The definition for `MLFloat16` is nowhere in the header files in distributed binaries, so I wonder what should be done to actually use `MLFloat16`. I'm not experienced in C++, so maybe I am missing a simple thing.

You can find the definition in  https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/db9c1308a5c6f159d49f9466e5104c59375eb57c/include/onnxruntime/core/framework/data_types.h#L55-L56

You can include the header file data_types.h in your code.

I am assuming a scenario such that the a user with downloaded onnxruntime binary compiles an application. In that case, he will not have `data_types.h` unless this repository is cloned. Is this inevitable?

I looked at the zip file in release binary, and it does not contain data_types.h. I think user might meet such problem using onnxruntime binary.

@pranavsharma to look at support float16 in onnxruntime binary.

You can use [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/60047308/12627730) to convert a float to float16 and then call CreateTensorWithDataAsOrtValue with type=ONNX_TENSOR_ELEMENT_DATA_TYPE_FLOAT16. I guess we should've an example in our tests to demonstrate it. We'll add one. For now this should work.

I have already tried that before like this:
```
    inputTensors.emplace_back(Ort::Value::CreateTensor(
      memoryInfo,
      inputBuffers->userBinaryInputBufferFP16,
      inputNodeSizes[0],
      inputNodeShape[0].data(),
      inputNodeShape[0].size(),
      ONNX_TENSOR_ELEMENT_DATA_TYPE_FLOAT16
    ));
```
, however the tensor could be not created and the application terminated in runtime with `abort() has been called` error.

Our API does not provide any conversions. 
The user is assumed to have the input values in the user supplied buffer as we don't want to do any copying as the inputs tend to be very large. The data type in question for float16 (as well as bfloat16) is really expressed in terms of uint16_t and it is possible to use it in C API. However, there is a shortcoming in C++. I am working to have this working along with a working example.

To feed a float16 into the API, you can call a non-templated version of Ort::Value::CreateTensor() and pass a pointer to the buffer. The last argument must have a value of ONNX_TENSOR_ELEMENT_DATA_TYPE_FLOAT16. Each float16 is assumed to be of size uitn16_t which is two bytes. 
The above referenced PR allows you to use a templated version. You can call CreateTensor<Ort::Float16_t>() which will do the same thing for you as above but will automatically set the last argument.
@isty2e Your idea of feeding the data could have worked. What makes you think it did not work? The above PR does essentially what you wanted to do.
Alternatively, we can add a Cast (float->fp16) node on the model input. In this way, the model takes in float and then cast it to fp16 internally.

> Alternatively, we can add a Cast (float->fp16) node on the model input. In this way, the model takes in float and then cast it to fp16 internally.

I would rather choose a solution that doesn't impact the time spent in Run(), even if it's minimal :-).

> > Alternatively, we can add a Cast (float->fp16) node on the model input. In this way, the model takes in float and then cast it to fp16 internally.
> 
> I would rather choose a solution that doesn't impact the time spent in Run(), even if it's minimal :-).

For most language, like C++, it doesn't have fp16 support natively. And in general, the actual input of model is fp32, so you need to cast fp32 to fp16 anyway.

> For sure, we need to have API support for fp16. This is an alternative. 
The APi already supports it. The important thing to remember that it expects a continuous buffer of 16-bit elements. Does your type contains such elements and is the size of your type is also 16-bit?

> @isty2e Your idea of feeding the data could have worked. What makes you think it did not work? The above PR does essentially what you wanted to do.

I thought so, but the application was terminated at runtime while creating the tensor. FP32 counterpart just worked.

> > > > Alternatively, we can add a Cast (float->fp16) node on the model input. In this way, the model takes in float and then cast it to fp16 internally.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > I would rather choose a solution that doesn't impact the time spent in Run(), even if it's minimal :-).
> > 
> > 
> > For most language, like C++, it doesn't have fp16 support natively. And in general, the actual input of model is fp32, so you need to cast fp32 to fp16 anyway.

The part of the actual input to the model fp32 is not true. The current API puts the conversion into the client space. We accept fp16 as a buffer of 16-bits bits.

> > @isty2e Your idea of feeding the data could have worked. What makes you think it did not work? The above PR does essentially what you wanted to do.
> 
> I thought so, but the application was terminated at runtime while creating the tensor. FP32 counterpart just worked.
The issue here is that we do not do any validation. If the buffer is shorter than the supplied shape we can read beyond the mapped memory. If you supply fp32 and say it is fp16, no conversion is taking place and we simply interpret fp32 bits as two consecutive fp16 which is garbage. We, of course, read only half of the buffer and do not SEGFAULT but it does not mean it works.

> The issue here is that we do not do any validation. If the buffer is shorter than the supplied shape we can read beyond the mapped memory. If you supply fp32 and say it is fp16, no conversion is taking place and we simply interpret fp32 bits as two consecutive fp16 which is garbage. We, of course, read only half of the buffer and do not SEGFAULT but it does not mean it works.

The data were exactly sized and converted to `uint16_t` beforehand, where both the aforementioned method and one using `half_float::detail::float2half<std::round_to_nearest>` have been tested. That's why I opened this issue in the first place. For the time being, I am just attaching FP16 <-> FP32 casting nodes in the input/output layers.
What is the library that you use? Where `half_float` comes from? Is it possible for you to share the model or a minimal repro model where experience the crash?

> What is the library that you use? Where `half_float` comes from? Is it possible for you to share the model or a minimal repro model where experience the crash?

`half_float` is from http://half.sourceforge.net/, but it is a minor detail; I have tested various methods including those two. A sample model is here: [b10_fp16.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/files/5503264/b10_fp16.zip), which is quantized with onnxmltools. The crash happens exactly at `CreateTensor`.
The API with element type expects byte count not element count
Oh indeed. Now the model runs without any problem.
How to input fp16 format data, can you give a code example ？
@isty2e Can you give a code example ？

Is a code sample available now?

The only solution is to add a cast layer in the model?
Please, let us know what is missing [here](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/main/include/onnxruntime/core/session/onnxruntime_cxx_api.h#L123)
Thanks, I'll try that when possible. For now, I have patched my model to force float32 on the output.

> To feed a float16 into the API, you can call a non-templated version of Ort::Value::CreateTensor() and pass a pointer to the buffer. The last argument must have a value of ONNX_TENSOR_ELEMENT_DATA_TYPE_FLOAT16. Each float16 is assumed to be of size uitn16_t which is two bytes. The above referenced PR allows you to use a templated version. You can call CreateTensorOrt::Float16_t() which will do the same thing for you as above but will automatically set the last argument.

hi, I create input tensor this way, but lt does not work, did I missed something? 
```cpp
Ort::Value input_tensor = Ort::Value::CreateTensor(memory_info, input_tensor_values.data(),
					patchSize[0]*patchSize[1]*patchSize[2], input_node_dims.data(), 5,
					ONNX_TENSOR_ELEMENT_DATA_TYPE_FLOAT16);
```
